DESCRIPTION: The proposal is for a 32-storey residential building.   A total gross floor area of 24,846m2 and a FSI of 4.99 x the lot area.  The proposed building will contain 358 units and 122 parking spaces in the two level below grade garage accessed from the public laneway to the west of the subject site.  A privately owned publically accessible park will be provided for a total area of 363 m2, in addition, to the required on-site parkland dedication of 481.9m2.
To construct a pergola on the terrace of Suite 5B on the fifth floor.

Plan of Subdivison application for lands at 440 Front Street West and various addresses associated with the redevelopment of the former Globe and Mail site ('The Well').  The purpose of the plan of subdivision is to allow for the consolidation of parcels and the subsequent  creation and conveyancing of stratified interest in this mixed-use development.  The applicant has also filed a Part Lot control application to allow for the lifting of Part Lot Control provisions (file no. 18 135656 STE 20 PL).  The lands are also subject to an Official Plan amendment and Zoning By-law amendment application (14 116571 STE 20 OZ).  Both the OPA and Zoning are in force.   There are five site plan control applications currently under review on the lands.

The proposal is for a 32-storey residential building containing 358 units with a building height of 104 metres.  A  total of 172 parking spaces will be provided in 3 levels of underground parking accessed by a widened public north--south laneway  from Holmes Ave.  A total of 358 bicycle parking spaces will be provided on the mezzanine level (208 spaces) and the underground garage (150 spaces).     A total  gross floor area of 24,846m2 is proposed, resulting in a FSI of 4.99 x lot area.  The applicant submitted a Rental Housing Demolition application to demolish two rental dwelling units on June 19, 2018.

Application proposes a condominium apartment building on the southern portion of the site and rental townhouse and apartment buildng units on the northern half of the site. The condominium compomemt comprises a 3 to 17-storey apartment building wing along the south edge of the site connected to a 4 to 11-storey apartment building wing along the Leslie Street containing a total of 499 dwelling units and 629 parking spaces. The existing rental townhouse units on the site managed by Toronto Community Housing would be replaced and are proposed on the northern portion of the site and would comprise 115 rental replacement units in two 2, 3-storey townhouse blocks containing a total of 48 units and a 4-storey apartment building along Leslie Sttreet containing 67 dweliing units. The redevelopment of the site also includes a new public road and a privately owned publicly-accessible open space.  The lands are also subject to applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law (File No. 11 330323 NNY 33 OZ), Rental Housing Demolition (11 331382 NNY 33 RH) and Draft Plan of Subdivision (14 134708 NNY 33 SB).

To permit the redevelopment of the 60 acre subject site into a new community  consisting of: office buildings (including the retention of the Celestica headquarters); commercial and retail space; 4,921 residential units within a range of building types including tall buildings, mid-rise buildings and low-rise town houses; land for a community centre, new public roads, open spaces and parks.The proposal will be developed in phases, in conjunction with the Don Mills Crossing Study. The Study is a comprehensive review of the anticipated growth around the intersection of Don Mills Road and Eglinton Avenue East and builds on the work of Eglinton Connects. The Study  will result in a new planning framework which will include implementation measures to support co-ordinated development of employment, residential and community uses. The current application is a revision to the May 2014 Official Plan Amendment application (14 153614 NNY 26 OZ) and submission of new Zoning By-law Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision applications.

Redevelopment of the subject properties for a 51-storey rental building, with retail uses at grade. As part of these applications they are also proposing to reconfigure St. James Town West Park, and make significant improvements to it. The existing heritage designated building at 601 Sherbourne Street (known as the Thomas Cruttenden Building) will be retained and no changes will be made to the existing rental units within the building. The existing underground parking garage on the Block will be modified to connect below grade to the new building. The new building will have a total Gross Floor Area (GFA) of approximately 34600 square metres, of which approximately 400 square metres will be atgrade retail space. A total of 532 new rental residential units are proposed. The new development will result in a total of 2057 units of market rental units (in bachelor, one-bedroom, two-bedroom and three-bedroom configurations) on the Block and an overall Floor Space Index (FSI) of 7.38

The site is located at the northwest corner of Midland Ave and St Clair Ave E.  The site is triangular in nature and has a site area of 1.52 ha. The rezoning application is to rezone the site from Industrial Commercial Zone (MC) in the Scarborough Employment District Zoning By-law No. 24982 to Townhouse Residential (TH) in the Midland/St. Clair Zoning By-law No. 842-2002 to permit a 48 townhouse unit development in five building blocks and to introduce site specific provisions including setbacks, height (at 3 storeys) and visitor parking standards.  The plan of subdivision is to create a public street and blocks for the townhouse development.

The Draft Plan of Condominium intends to unitize the individual 291 residential condominium units, 246 lockers, 196 parking spaces, shared facilities, the daycare space, as well as the 5 rental parking units and 2 rental locker units. These unitized parking spaces and lockers will be transferred back to the owners of the rental buildings following the registration of the Condominium Corporation. The application would also facilitate the creation of easements on the ground floor and the daycare for the outdoor play area, as well as shared access easements for the drive aisles, exit stairs, mechanical rooms, loading/driveway areas and privately-owned publicly-accessible spaces (POPS). (36R Tippett - West Building).

The site is located at the northwest corner of Midland Ave and St Clair Ave E.  The site is triangular in nature and has a site area of 1.52 ha.  A branch of the CNR is located along the northwest boundary of the stie.  The CNR right-of-way is separated from the site by an existing safety berm.  The rezoning application is to rezone the site from Industrial Commercial Zone (MC) in the Scarborough Employment District Zoning By-law No. 24982 to Townhouse Residential (TH) in the Midland/St. Clair Zoning By-law No. 842-2002 to permit a 48 townhouse unit development in five building blocks and to introduce site specific provisions including setbacks, height (at 3 storeys) and visitor parking standards.  The plan of subdivision is to create a public street and blocks for the townhouse development.

Revised proposal for 10, 3-storey townhouses (2 blocks of 5 each) fronting onto Marlee Avenue. 20 parking spaces (one in a garage) located at grade at the rear accessed via a driveway to Wenderley Drive. Proposal consists of 3 lots. Concurrent Site Plan Application. Proposal consists of 3 lots.

CONVENIENCE ADDRESS FOR 50 BRUYERES MEWS (BLOCK 4) - revised Aug 2 - Site Plan approval application  to construct new 15 storey residential building - 249 residential units - 4 levels below grade parking - 215 parking spaces 240 Bicycle parking spaces. - See 12 116214 ZPR for existing PPR.

The original application proposed a zoning by-law amendment and sought rental housing demolition and replacement approval to permit the redevelopment of the site with a total of 886 residential units ranging in buildings from 10 to 32 storeys in height, ground floor retail and a public parkette.  The second submission proposed the demolition of the two existing apartment buildings and the redevelopment of the site with a total of 842 residential units.  This included 33 stacked townhouses on the east side of the site, plus three buildings, one of which would contain ground floor retail, would range in height from 12 to 28 storeys and would contain 663 condominium units.  A public park fronting Brimorton Drive is also proposed.  The 141 rental units would be replaced with 146 rental units in a new 16 storey building.  This revised submission reduces the building heights of the two buildings fronting Markham Road from 28 storeys to 24 storeys, which reduces the number of units in these two buildings from 553 to 473.  The revised rental replacement building will provide 29 three bedroom units and will also provide five, family oriented, grade accessible units located on the ground floor.  As a result of the changes, the overall unit count has been reduced to 762 dwelling units.

Condo Building B known as 30 Meadowglen Place.  File created as sub-folder to 13 199513 ESC 38 SA. Revised site plan application based on OMB Case No. PL131280 proposes the redevelopment of the site with 32 stacked townhouses, a 16 storey, 146 residential unit rental apartment building, and three condominium buildings ranging in height from 14 to 28 storeys, containing 765 dwellings units.  A total of 943 dwelling units are proposed in the overall development of the site.  A 1,752 square metre public park is proposed fronting Brimorton Drive and approximately 1,051 square metres of ground floor commercial space is also proposed in the buildings fronting Markham Road.

The original application proposed a zoning by-law amendment and sought rental housing demolition and replacement approval to permit the redevelopment of the site with a total of 886 residential units ranging in buildings from 10 to 32 storeys in height, ground floor retail and a public parkette.  The second submission proposed the demolition of the two existing apartment buildings and the redevelopment of the site with a total of 842 residential units.  This included 33 stacked townhouses on the east side of the site, plus three buildings, one of which would contain ground floor retail, would range in height from 12 to 28 storeys and would contain 663 condominium units.  A public park fronting Brimorton Drive is also proposed.  The 141 rental units would be replaced with 146 rental units in a new 16 storey building.  This revised submission reduces the building heights of the two buildings fronting Markham Road from 28 storeys to 24 storeys, which reduces the number of units in these two buildings from 553 to 473.  The revised rental replacement building will provide 29 three bedroom units and will also provide five, family oriented, grade accessible units located on the ground floor.  As a result of the changes, the overall unit count has been reduced to 762 dwelling units.

The Site Plan Application for a 13-story mixed-use building consisting of approximately 228 residential condominium units, 3,112 sq.m. of ground floor retail (approximately 33, 497 sf), and approximately 342 vehicular parking spaces for resident, tenant and visitor use. Parking is distributed on four below grade levels, interspersed with approximately 330 bicycle parking spaces. The residential condominium component of the building has been designed to accommodate families of all sizes (61 % lBO, 34% 2BD and 5% 3BD).

Part Lot Exemption Application to permit 155 freehold townhouses on Blocks 1, 2, 3 and 6 within the Stanley Greene Block G District Plan. Each townhouse has a single or double car garage that is accessed via an 8m common element laneway located at the rear of the townhouses. Garbage storage and pickup will occur in the common element laneway. This application is related to Common Element Condominium Application #20 143006 NNY 06 CD (parent Sub-division Approval File #15 172297 NNY 09 SB, and related Site Plan Application Files 16 268887 NNY 09 SA and 16 268941 NNY 09 SA).

A zoning by-law amendment and draft plan of subdivision application have been submitted to permit the development of the lands at 222 Centennial Road and 35 Acheson Boulevard.  These applications propose to establish a total of twenty detached dwellings. The proposal contemplates access to fourteen detached dwellings via a new 16.5 metre public road intersecting Centennial Road. The remaining six detached dwellings would front onto Acheson Boulevard.

The applications were appealed by the applicant to the Ontario Municipal Board, citing a lack of decision by City Council. A hearing date has been set for February 4, 2015.

Proposal to permit the construction of an 88-unit stacked townhouse development located in 5 building blocks.  This proposed development represents Phase 5 of the Davenport Village Area Development.

Proposed Official Plan Amendment to the Davenport Village Secondary Plan and Zoning By-law Amendment to former City of Toronto Zoning By-law No. 438-86, as amended by Zoning By-law No. 728-2006, to permit the construction of three residential apartment buildings with heights of 12, 29, and 36 storeys with 7-storey podiums, two 4-storey stacked townhouse buildings, and a 1-storey daycare building.  The southern block previously referred to as 980 Lansdowne (Phase 6) and 900 Lansdowne (Phase 9) have been merged into one Phase 6.  30 Powerhouse is also part of this submission proposing mixed use.
To construct a new two-storey dwelling with an integral garage. The existing dwelling would be demolished.

To obtain consent to sever the property into two lots.  The retained lot will maintain a Toronto District School Board Public School (Fisherville Senior Public School). The severed lot will be redeveloped at a later date.
Rezoning application to permit the construction of a 41 storey building.  By-law 1067-2007, permits an 18 storey building on the lands.

Official Plan and Zoning By law amendment to permit the re-development of the lands for a new mixed use development complete with commercial and residential.  The redevelopment includes the retention of the existing building at the corner for commercial purposes, and the construction of 558 residential dwelling units in two towers.  734 parking spaces to serve the development are proposed, 611 of which will be located below grade.  Please note that City Planning will be preparing an amendment to the Davenport Village Secondary Plan to include this site within the Secondary Plan.

This application proposes to amend the Official Plan and Site Specific Zoning By-law 1994-197 and to lift the Holding (H) symbol to permit a 3-storey non-residential building fronting Lake Shore Boulevard West, a 436 unit, 49-storey residential tower on the central block of the development site, and a 186 unit, 14-storey residential building abutting Marine Parade Drive with ground-floor retail.
To obtain consent to create an easement/right-of-way for access purposes.

The application to amend the Zoning By-law proposes to permit a 23-storey addition to the east side of the existing 26-storey residential apartment building.  The total height of the proposed building addition including the mechanical penthouse is 73 metres.  The proposed addition steps down  to a 4-storey podium along Church Street.  It contains 211 dwelling units including 199 residential rental units as well as 12 residential condominium units located on the top two floors.   The applicant is proposing to reduce the amount of underground parking from 183 parking spaces to 166 parking spaces to accommodate the new elevator and stair core.

Zoning by law amendment applicaiton to permit the redevelopmetn of the land for a new 7 unit infill townhouse development (Freehold) serviced by common element driveway leading to private parking to the rear of each unit.  Each unit to front onto a municipal street..  Seperate application for common element condo to follow.
To obtain consent to sever portions of the land for the purpose of lot additions and to create various easements.

In its decision of August 2, 2012, the Committee of Adjustment approved an application to sever the subject site to create two residential lots. At that time, the applicant did not seek relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to create the lots and filed a waiver indicating that no variances would be required with respect to lot frontage and area.  The applicant is now proposing to develop each of these lots with a two-storey single family dwelling and is requesting relief from the Zoning By-law to facilitate this development, as well as, to allow reduced lot frontages and areas.

In its decision of August 2, 2012, the Committee of Adjustment approved an application to sever the subject site into two residential lots.  At that time, the applicant did not seek relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to create the lots.  The applicant is now proposing to construct a two-storey single family detached house on each lot with the following requested minor variances, including lot frontage and lot area.

In January, 2013, the Committee of Adjustment approved variances for two houses on lots that were created by severance. The Committee approved variances to permit a building coverage of 36.2% on each lot. A zoning examination has revealed that the proposed building coverage would actually be greater than the variances approved by the Committee, and the applicant is now requesting additional relief from the Zoning By-law.

In January, 2013, the Committee of Adjustment approved variances for a house on a lot that was created by severance. The Committee approved variances to permit a building coverage of 36.2%. A zoning examination has revealed that the proposed building coverage would actually be greater than the variance approved by the Committee, and the applicant is now requesting additional relief from the Zoning By-law.

This application is for a severance to create a parcel of land at the northeast corner of Morningside Avenue and Milner Avenue for future development, along with an easement for access. Part 1 on the attached Lot Division Plan (the conveyed lot) will have an area of 5,801 m² and is intended to be conveyed for future development. Part 2 (the proposed easement) will have an area of 570 m² and is intended to allow mutual use of a drive aisle for access to the severed lot. Part 2 will remain in common ownership with the retained lands to the south (including the Business Depot lands).

This application is for a variance to establish a single minimum parking requirement for all uses in the shopping centre. The Zoning By-law requires a minimum of 5 parking spaces per 100 m2 of gross floor area for personal service shops and retail stores, and 10.7 parking spaces per 100 m2 of gross floor area for sit-down restaurants or quick service take-out restaurants. The owners propose to owners propose to establish a parking rate for all uses that would correspond to the existing number of parking spaces.

Zoning By-law Amendment application for a proposed 19-lot detached residential subdivision involving the eastward extension of Woodgrove Drive to Bennett Road. Revised Rezoning application submitted December 21, 2011 for new residential condo building to permit a mixed use development with one 58-storey tower (was 186.7 metres revised to 182 metres including mechanical) containing originally 570 now 474 residential condominium units on a 4-storey podium now 3-storey.  There were originally two lobbies proposed, one from Hayden Street and one from Charles Street East and the applicant has now revised that to one lobby on Charles Street East.    There are five levels of below grade parking with originally 215 now 141 (including 8 car share) vehicular parking spaces.  Access is from a two way lane on the west side of the site running between Charles Street and Hayden Street.  There are 475 bicycle parking spaces proposed.   Amenity space is to be provided within the podium.  Other revisions include reduction in site area from 2,509 to 2142 sq.m.; reduction in gross floor area from 36,500 to 29,500 sq.m.; reduction in tower floor plate from 700 to 540 sq.m.; green wall along Hayden Street.  The application was approved by the OMB in its decision dated September 21, 2012.  Site specific by-law  7-2013(OMB).

Provision for a future east-west mid-building connection will be secured through the existing 350 Queens Quay West building.

Proposal Description:

Submission of a site plan application for the Retail and Office components of the development of the former Globe and Mail site (Master Sipe Plan submission). This application includes the underground parking, retail and office components of the site plan application to permit a comprehensive development of the former Globe and Mail site (aka. The Well).  The project, now under construction, includes seven mixed-use buildings comprising retail, office and residential uses.  A maximum of 289,000 square metres of gross floor area includes 102,797 square metres office space; 47,290 square metres of retail space and 132,923 square metres of residential space.  A total of 1,681 residential units are proposed.  See Zoning By-laws 124-2017 and 125-2017.  Four site plan applications have been submitted and are under review comprising the residential component of the development.

To construct a new townhouse development. The development will consist of a total of 19 dwelling units.

The building would have a total gross floor area of approximately 2,938 square metres

The applicant is seeking relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to expand the existing food store (Skyland Food Supermarket) use into the  adjoining space (Unit 3701-B) and to add two mezzanine within the existing spaces (Unit 3711 and Unit 3715).  On January 2009, the Committee of Adjustment approved 2284 square metres of food retail use.

The interior of the Guild Inn would be adaptively reused to accommodate restaurant and office uses. Additions added to the building over time would be removed, and the exterior would be restored to its 1932 appearance. The new banquet facility would be 2,081 square metres (22,404 square feet) in size and located west of the Guild Inn building, while the new ceremonial building would be approximately 389 square metres (4,187 square feet) in size and constructed to the east.  Approximately 300 parking spaces are proposed (which include both existing and new spaces).

Site plan approval for a new retail food store with a mezzanine level, total GFA of 3560 square metres, as well as a one-storey retail pad site of 278 square metres.  There is an existing TD Bank on the site which is not proposed to be altered. Comments on first submission circulation were provided to applicant in April 2013.  Awaiting resubmission.

Zoning Bylaw Amendment application to permit 3, 14-storey mixed use towers and a 13-storey office building. The proposal includes a total of 818 residential units, and 3,239sqm of retail space. The proposed development has a combined Gross Floor Area of 70,301.30sqm and a Floor Space Index of 4.25. A 3 level shared underground parking structure would provide a total of 821 parking spaces.

Site Plan Control Application for the combined sites at 100, 110, 114 and 120 Broadway Avenue and 223-233 Redpath Avenue. These files were previously processed under two separate OZ folders: 15 228723 NNY 25 OZ (100 Broadway Ave and 223-225 Redpath Ave) and 17 218847 NNY 25 OZ (110, 114 and 120 Broadway Ave) and were approved at the LPAT in August 2019.  The development consists of 3 towers. A 36-storey purpose-built residential rental building containing 412 units with 100 square metres of retail space at-grade is proposed on the 100 Broadway Avenue portion.  Two residential towers at 33- and 21-storeys in height, connected by a 4 to 8-storey base building containing 741 residential units and 606 square metres of office space is proposed on the 110-120 Broadway Avenue portion. The site has a combined total of 326 vehicular parking spaces and 1,154 bicycle parking spaces within two levels of shared underground parking. Immediately south of the 100 Broadway Avenue building on the northeast corner of Broadway and Redpath Avenues is a new 746 square metre public park with surrounding POPS.

Draft Plan of Standard Condominium to permit 545 residential units and 4 guest suites, within two new residential towers (Tower H: 27-storeys, 236 residential units, 2 guest suites; Tower D: 34-Storeys, 309 residential units, 2 guest suites), with a 3-level shared below-grade garage, on a lot retained through the severance of two lots occupied by two existing apartment buildings.

Original rezoning application submitted for a mixed-use development consisting of two residential towers at 45 and 54 storeys in height with a 9-10 storey podium. The development proposes a total gross floor area of 90,700 square metres and will feature 1,304 dwelling units above a 1 storey of street-related retail space. The original proposal frames a public park on the south side of the block. The second submission proposed one 54-storey tower (181 metres) located at the north east corner of the site with 681 units, retail at grade and office in floor 2 and 3. Access to below grade parking and loading is proposed from St. Luke Lane. A public parking facility is also proposed below grade. The proposal also includes an expanded park space from Wellesley Street to Breadalbane Street. Resubmission April 2, 2014 adding in the parcel of land on the east side of St Luke Lane, reducing the area of the, increasing the area of the park, the tower height proposed is 60 storyes (194 metres including mechanical penthouse), revising the gross floor area, increasing the number of units to 742. The purpose of the rezoning application is to permit a 58-storey residential building comprised of a 5-storey podium and 53-storey tower.  Revision has been submitted including the following:  proposed height was 195 metres now 202 metres tall including the mechanical penthouse; proposed units was 513 now 472 units; proposed gross floor area of the building was 48,605 square metres which includes 734 square metres of ground floor retail uses now the gross floor area is proposed at 49,801 square metres including 850 square metres of retail space at grade and 5,580 square metres of office in the Wellington Street part of the podium.   The proposal previously included 365 car parking spaces and now includes 343 spaces in 5 levels of underground parking.  Other revisions include: changes to the main floor design, changes to the access off of Colborne Street to the internal loading area, vehicular access off of Wellington street has been deleted, atrium space on the main floor has been revised. The applicant is proposing to demolish the existing 7-storey structure and preserve and reuse its stone cladding for the new podium.   The applicant has advised it is their intent to develop this project as a condominium.

Official Plan and Zoning By-law Amendments to facilitate the revitalization of a large rental apartment building complex known as Wellesley-Parliament Square (located within St. James Town). The proposed development consists of:- changes to the ground floor layout and uses of the existing buildings- changes to the underground parking garage and configuration of loading and servicing areas- changes to the existing network of private streets and open spaces, including the proposed introduction of a public right-of-way (Rose Avenue) and a public park- the development of a new 51-storey tower with a 10-storey base building and 4-storey commercial base building (Builidng B2) - the development of a new 10-storey residential rental building (Building B1)- the development of a 5-storey non-residential building (Building B2) attached to 280 Wellesley St E- the development of four 3-storey townhouse blocks (A3, B3, B4, B5).The existing floor space index is 3.71 and the proposed floor space index is 5.49.  There are 2,224 existing dwelling units and an additional 887 proposed dwelling units.  There is 2,490 sq. metres of existing non-residential space and an additional 9,685 square metres of proposed non-residential space.  There are approximately 1,555 existing parking spaces and an additional 29 proposed parking spaces.

Revised application submitted February 25, 2019: The Applicant, Pinnacle International Group, has submitted a Site Plan Application for the development of the southeast portion (total area of 5,576.9 square metres) of their northern parcel at 1-7 Yonge Street. This specific application represents Phase 1 of the proposed 5-phased development (north and south parcel) at 1-7 Yonge Street. The proposal is for a 65-storey, 204.2 metre high, mixed-use building with a total GFA of 60,743 square metres (including a 4,772 square metre Community Centre on floors 1 and 2, 1,167 square metres of retail at grade and 54,804 square metres of residential/affordable housing on floors 1 to 65). The total FSI for Phase 1 is 10.89. A total of 596 residential units (including affordable housing units), along with 604 vehicular parking spaces and 750 bicycle parking spaces are proposed for this development application. The proposal also includes 1,192 square metres of indoor amenity space and 1,192 square metres of outdoor amenity space. The associated Official Plan and Rezoning Amendment application (#13 129256 STE 28 OZ) for the entire site (Phases 1-5) at 1-7 Yonge Street is before the LPAT. Council has endorsed proceeding to a settlement in accordance with the terms outlined in a Directions Report to TEYCC in June, 2016. The settlement hearing occured on March 20, 2017 (the LPAT endorsed the settlement in principle, and witheld its order subject to various matters being completed).

Revised application submitted June 27, 2018: The Applicant, Pinnacle International (Seven Yonge) Ltd., has submitted a Site Plan Application for the development of the northern parcel at 1-7 Yonge Street (this application is for Phases 2 & 3 of the overall development, whereas Site Plan File # 16 269114 STE 28 SA has been submitted for Phase 1 of the subject site, and circulated internally). This proposal is for a 95-storey, 307 metre high mixed-use building (Phase 2) and an 80-storey, 263.6 metre high mixed-use building (Phase 3) with a total GFA for both buildings of 177,377 square metres (the GFA includes 145,385 square metres of residential use in both buildings, 14,206 square metres of a hotel use in Phase 2, and 4,297 square metres of retail use in both buildings). The residential use GFA for Phase 3 is inclusive of 12,311 square metres devoted to affordable rental housing uses. The total FSI for Phases 2 and 3 is 26.9. A total of 1,820 residential units (including 120 affordable rental housing units) are proposed for Phases 2 and 3. The proposal also includes 852 vehicular parking spaces, 2,228 bicycle parking spaces, 3,517 square metres of indoor amenity and 3,400 square metres of outdoor amenity space to serve the development. The associated Official Plan and Rezoning Amendment Application (# 13 129256 STE 28 OZ) for the entire development (Phases 1 to 5) at 1-7 Yonge Street has been endorsed in principle by the LPAT. Council has endorsed proceeding to a settlement in accordance with the terms outlined in a Directions Report to TEYCC in June 2016.

Revised Rezoning application submitted December 21, 2011 for new residential condo building to permit a mixed use development with one 58-storey tower (was 186.7 metres revised to 182 metres including mechanical) containing originally 570 now 474 residential condominium units on a 4-storey podium now 3-storey.  There were originally two lobbies proposed, one from Hayden Street and one from Charles Street East and the applicant has now revised that to one lobby on Charles Street East.    There are five levels of below grade parking with originally 215 now 141 (including 8 car share) vehicular parking spaces.  Access is from a two way lane on the west side of the site running between Charles Street and Hayden Street.  There are 475 bicycle parking spaces proposed.   Amenity space is to be provided within the podium.  Other revisions include reduction in site area from 2,509 to 2142 sq.m.; reduction in gross floor area from 36,500 to 29,500 sq.m.; reduction in tower floor plate from 700 to 540 sq.m.; green wall along Hayden Street.  The application was approved by the OMB in its decision dated September 21, 2012.  Site specific by-law  7-2013(OMB).

Application proposes a condominium apartment building on the southern portion of the site and rental townhouse and apartment buildng units on the northern half of the site. The condominium compomemt comprises a 3 to 17-storey apartment building wing along the south edge of the site connected to a 4 to 11-storey apartment building wing along the Leslie Street containing a total of 499 dwelling units and 629 parking spaces. The existing rental townhouse units on the site managed by Toronto Community Housing would be replaced and are proposed on the northern portion of the site and would comprise 115 rental replacement units in two 2, 3-storey townhouse blocks containing a total of 48 units and a 4-storey apartment building along Leslie Sttreet containing 67 dweliing units. The redevelopment of the site also includes a new public road and a privately owned publicly-accessible open space.  The lands are also subject to applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law (File No. 11 330323 NNY 33 OZ), Rental Housing Demolition (11 331382 NNY 33 RH) and Draft Plan of Subdivision (14 134708 NNY 33 SB).

To permit the redevelopment of the 60 acre subject site into a new community  consisting of: office buildings (including the retention of the Celestica headquarters); commercial and retail space; 4,921 residential units within a range of building types including tall buildings, mid-rise buildings and low-rise town houses; land for a community centre, new public roads, open spaces and parks.The proposal will be developed in phases, in conjunction with the Don Mills Crossing Study. The Study is a comprehensive review of the anticipated growth around the intersection of Don Mills Road and Eglinton Avenue East and builds on the work of Eglinton Connects. The Study  will result in a new planning framework which will include implementation measures to support co-ordinated development of employment, residential and community uses. The current application is a revision to the May 2014 Official Plan Amendment application (14 153614 NNY 26 OZ) and submission of new Zoning By-law Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision applications.

The rezoning application is to rezone the site from Industrial Commercial Zone (MC) in the Scarborough Employment District Zoning By-law No. 24982 to Townhouse Residential (TH) in the Midland/St. Clair Zoning By-law No. 842-2002 to permit a 48 townhouse unit development in five building blocks and to introduce site specific provisions including setbacks, height (at 3 storeys) and visitor parking standards.  The plan of subdivision is to create a public street and blocks for the townhouse development.

The purpose of the Official Plan and Zoning By-law amendment application is to permit a 29-storey residential building including an L-shaped 8 to 12-storey base building.  The proposed building contains 518 residential dwelling units including 44,634 square metres of residential gross floor area.  The application also includes 374 square metres of non-residential uses on the ground floor. The applicant is proposing 477 parking spaces in a 4-level underground parking structure. In addition to the tower, the proposal also includes a new building that would contain a car dealership with a total area of 3,577.8 square metres.

The Local Planning Appeal Tribunal (LPAT) decision of July 20, 2018 approved in principle the redevelopment of the site (5840-5870 Yonge St) for mixed-use development.  Refer to Case Number PL160863.  This site plan application proposes a 32-storey residential building containing 408 dwelling units and three levels of underground parking.  The total gross floor area proposed is 33,205 square metres.  A park of 734 square metres is also proposed at the south-east corner of the site.  A future site plan application will be filed for 5870 Yonge Street for an automotive dealership with 3,763 square metres of gross floor area.  The residential building will also be provided vehicular access from the driveway serving the automotive dealership with mutual access easements from an associated consent application.

The Local Planning Appeal Tribunal (LPAT) decision of July 20, 2018 approved in principle the redevelopment of the site for a residential condominium building and an automotive dealership. The residential condo building will also be provided vehicular access from the driveway serving the automotive dealership with mutual access easements from an associated consent application. Application proposes a condominium apartment building on the southern portion of the site and rental townhouse and apartment buildng units on the northern half of the site. The condominium compomemt comprises a 3 to 17-storey apartment building wing along the south edge of the site connected to a 4 to 11-storey apartment building wing along the Leslie Street containing a total of 499 dwelling units and 629 parking spaces. The existing rental townhouse units on the site managed by Toronto Community Housing would be replaced and are proposed on the northern portion of the site and would comprise 115 rental replacement units in two 2, 3-storey townhouse blocks containing a total of 48 units and a 4-storey apartment building along Leslie Sttreet containing 67 dweliing units. The redevelopment of the site also includes a new public road and a privately owned publicly-accessible open space. The site is located at the northwest corner of Midland Ave and St Clair Ave E.  The site is triangular in nature and has a site area of 1.52 ha.  A branch of the CNR is located along the northwest boundary of the stie.  The CNR right-of-way is separated from the site by an existing safety berm.  The rezoning application is to rezone the site from Industrial Commercial Zone (MC) in the Scarborough Employment District Zoning By-law No. 24982 to Townhouse Residential (TH) in the Midland/St. Clair Zoning By-law No. 842-2002 to permit a 48 townhouse unit development in five building blocks and to introduce site specific provisions including setbacks, height (at 3 storeys) and visitor parking standards.  The plan of subdivision is to create a public street and blocks for the townhouse development.

Site Plan Approval application to facilitate the development of Block 4 of the former LCBO lands, part of the comprehensively planned Lower Yonge Precinct.  Blocks 1 and 2 of the LCBO lands are already under development, and Block 3 will be conveyed as a City Park. The proposal will be comprised of 3 towers having heights of 79, 87, and 90 storeys atop 2 mixed-use podiums.  Podiums will include preserved and reintegrated elements from the existing historic LCBO office and warehouse buildings.  The south podium includes a 929 m² daycare and space for a 5,271 m² elementary public school.  A total of 16,165 m² of non-residential floor area is proposed as well as 216, 742 m² of residential GFA - 2,705 market residential units and 196 affordable housing units.

Submission of a site plan application for the Retail and Office components of the development of the former Globe and Mail site (Master Sipe Plan submission). The project, now under construction, includes seven mixed-use buildings comprising retail, office and residential uses. Four site plan applications have been submitted and are under review comprising the residential component of the development.

The proposed development consists of:- changes to the ground floor layout and uses of the existing buildings- changes to the underground parking garage and configuration of loading and servicing areas- changes to the existing network of private streets and open spaces, including the proposed introduction of a public right-of-way (Rose Avenue) and a public park- the development of a new 51-storey tower with a 10-storey base building and 4-storey commercial base building (Builidng B2) - the development of a new 10-storey residential rental building (Building B1)- the development of a 5-storey non-residential building (Building B2) attached to 280 Wellesley St E- the development of four 3-storey townhouse blocks (A3, B3, B4, B5).The existing floor space index is 3.71 and the proposed floor space index is 5.49.  There are 2,224 existing dwelling units and an additional 887 proposed dwelling units.  There is 2,490 sq. metres of existing non-residential space and an additional 9,685 square metres of proposed non-residential space.  There are approximately 1,555 existing parking spaces and an additional 29 proposed parking spaces.

A Zoning By-law Amendment to redevelop the site with a mixed-use development that would include one north building (5-storey podium stepping up to 9, 12 and 15-storeys), one south building (17-storeys), one office building (8-storeys), and a new public park (868 square metres). The proposal includes a total gross floor area of 55,651 square metres, of which 7,868 square metres for office space, 1,272 square metres for commercial space, and 763 square metres for a day care. This site would contain a total of 517 new residential units, of which 480 would be condominium units and 37 would be affordable units. A total of 351 vehicular parking spaces are proposed above grade and to be located along the rail corridor. An Official Plan Amendment application (under File Number  13 278533 WET 11 OZ) is currently under appeal at the Local Planning Appeal Tribunal (the "LPAT"). This is a revised Official Plan and Zoning By-law amendment to permit a mixed-use development consisting of three towers of 24, 16 to 28 and 37 storeys. The base building heights range from 3 to 5 storeys, with certain massing components that are 12 storeys. The revised proposal includes 1,468 dwelling units, 124 hotel rooms, 54,702 sq.m. of non-residential space, 821 vehicular parking spaces, and 1,687 bicycle parking spaces. A 1,400 sq.m. public park is proposed fronting on Queen St. E., along with a proposed privately-owned publicly accessible space (POPS) in the form of a walkway to connect Queen St. E. to Richmond St. E. The Official Plan amendment has been revised to include an amendment to policy 3.2.1.6 to allow for the proposed rental replacement units. This application is associated with the Rental Housing Demolition application, file no. 17 160339 STE 28 RH. On August 23, 2017, the LPAT approved a settlement for three towers of 25, 24 and 32 storeys.

Site Plan application to permit the construction of four buildings on the block bounded by Lower Sherbourne Street, Princess Avenue, The Esplanade and Front Street  East. It is proposed to construct two 29-storey buildings connected by a 16-storey building that steps down to a 10-storey building to the south. The two 29-storey buildings step down three times along Lower Sherbourne Street and Princess Street reaching a height of 11-storeys along The Esplanade. Along The Esplanade, a Privately Owned Publically Accessible space measuring 1,608 sq.m. is provided. In total, the buildings would include 1,927 sq.m. of non-residential uses and 1,531 residential units. This is the first residential application (Block 12) for Site Plan Control related to the redevelopment of the former Celestica lands, now known as Crosstown. 

This application proposes the construction of three towers of 32, 34 and 39 storeys atop a podium ranging from 2 to 5 storeys, a portion of which is the retained facade of the Parkin Building.  Also proposed on the site is an 8 storey mid-rise, and 18 three storey back-to-back townhouses. Eight if the 18 townhouses are proposed to be affordable ownership units.

A POPS connection is proposed through the site, connecting further public Street C with Block 14B, which will be open space. A zoning by-law amendment and draft plan of subdivision application have been submitted to permit the development of the lands at 222 Centennial Road and 35 Acheson Boulevard.  These applications propose to establish a total of twenty detached dwellings. The proposal contemplates access to fourteen detached dwellings via a new 16.5 metre public road intersecting Centennial Road. The remaining six detached dwellings would front onto Acheson Boulevard.

The applications were appealed by the applicant to the Ontario Municipal Board, citing a lack of decision by City Council. A hearing date has been set for February 4, 2015.

Rezoning application (16 119194 ESC 36 OZ) and a Site Plan Control Application (16 119197 ESC 36 SA) for a 3-storey, stacked townhouse development containing 101 units (1 to 3 bedrooms) and 710 square metres of ground floor retail uses along Kingston Road. The building is located along the property's Kingston Road frontage and Mason Road frontage with two "alcoves" or openings on Kingston Road which allows views into the site as well as provide for pedestrian connections to the sidewalk/street.  Three rows of townhouses are proposed from the "main"  building segment along Kingston Road with the row of townhouses separated by shared courtyards and outdoor areas, common gardens and amenity spaces.  Parking for the development (125 parking spaces) is to be located entirely within the one level underground parking structure.  84 bicycle parking spaces are proposed. NOTE: The original submission was for a stacked townhouse development with 104 units and 776 square metres of ground floor retail uses along Kingston Road, 128 parking spaces and 103 visitor parking spaces.

Revised Submission Received on June 2, 2016: Daniels Leslieville Corp. have submitted revised rezoning (File #15 214416 STE 30 OZ) and site plan (File #15 214418 STE 30 SA) applications to permit the development of a 6 storey mixed-use building, with a maximum height of 20.0 metres (23.5 metres to the roof of the mechanical penthouse) and a maximum FSI of 3.79. The proposed building will maintain at grade retail fronting Queen Street East, three grade-related residential units fronting onto the public laneway to the south and 5 storeys of residential units above. In total, 69 residential units are proposed, with a gross floor area of approximately 5,372.8 square meters and 320.7 square metres of retail at grade. The proposal includes 37 parking spaces in one level of below-grade parking, which includes 4 visitor parking spaces. The proposal also includes 84 bicycle parking spaces located at grade, which includes 11 visitor bike parking spaces.

This application proposes to amend the Zoning By-laws to permit a 26-storey mixed use building with an 8-storey podium.  The development would have a total of 29,929 m2 of gross floor area, of which 2,371 m2 would be for non-residential uses.  The development would contain approximately 385 residential units and a total of 258 vehicular parking spaces.  An Official Plan Amendment (under File Number 16 269352 WET 06 OZ) was submitted in December 2016, was refused by City Council in May 2017 and is currently under appeal to the Ontario Municipal Board.  This Zoning By-law Amendment application is currently under appeal to the Ontario Municipal Board.
The applicant is seeking relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to construct a new two storey single family residential dwelling.
Proposed new single family detached house.
New single family dwelling with an integral garage (347 m2)

Draft Plan of Standard Condominium application for Block 26 (Phase 3 - Regent Park) to create 343 dwelling units within a mixed-use development comprised of a 27-storey tower and 6 storey podium with two levels of below-grade parking.
OPA and Rezoning application for a new 11 storey mixed use building - 109 residential suites - 3 levels below grade parking - 125 bicycle parking spaces - 4 retail units at grade.

Revised proposal for one 21-storey residential tower including a 3-storey base building at 174-188 Soudan Avenue and 71 and 73 Redpath Avenue.  The proposed development site no longer includes the property at 18 Brownlow Avenue.
To construct a rear two storey addition and a concrete deck.

Rezoning application to create 86 townhouse units and a new public road. A mixtures of freehold street townhouses with integral garages, street townhouses with rear parking and and back-to-back townhouses are proposed. An open space land dedication is proposed along the south property line to be combined with the existing open space to the south.

Rezoning application to permit a 55-storey residential tower fronting Charles Street East connected to a 8-storey office building fronting Hayden Street.  The overall development would have a total gross floor area of 45,764 square metres, with 36,598 square metres of residential floor area (622 dwelling units) and 9,166 square metres of non-residential floor area.  A total of 213 automobile parking spaces are proposed in a four level underground parking garage.

The applicant proposes to obtain approval to permit 3 semi-detached lots (6 dwelling units) and 14 single detached lots on a new 18. 5 m wide public street as the original proposal contemplated a similar proposal on a 16.5 metre public road.

Site plan approval submission to permit the construction of 314 residential units, and a minimum of 50,000 square feet of commercial space.  Located along the Warden Avenue frontage at Deans Drive will be a mid-rise mixed use building containing a maximum of 130 apartment units and a minimum of 17,200 square feet of commercial space on the ground floor.  Two commercial totalling over 32,700 square feet are located further north on the site. The remainder of the site will be occupied by a stormwater management pond and a City park.

The applicant is seeking relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to recognize existing non conforming conditions.  NOTE: This proposal has been reviewed under the Birchcliff Community By-law, and the new Toronto Zoning By-law which was enacted by the City Council at its meeting on August 25-27, 2010.

To construct a new three-storey dwelling. The existing dwelling would be demolished.

To construct a new front porch and a two-storey rear addition.

To obtain consent to sever the property into two residential lots.  The retained lot will maintain the existing dwelling and the severed (conveyed) lot will be redeveloped as the site of a new residential dwelling fronting Jedburgh Road.  The existing detached garage will be demolished.

To maintain the existing dwelling as constructed.  The variance request is a result of the related severance application (B065/14NY).  Committee of Adjustment applications B065/14NY, A877/14NY, and A878/14NY will be jointly considered.

Urban intensification for the northwest corner of Peter St and Richmond St. W.,  134 Peter St. will remain as is; 364-370 Richmond St. W. will become intergrated in the proposed 17 storey development. To construct a new two-storey detached dwelling with an integral garage. The existing dwelling would be demolished.

Three storey townhouse development containing 7 dwelling units facing Bayview Avenue.  Vehicular parking to the townhouses will be accessed via a rear driveway from Valley Rd.  Each townhouse will have an integral double car garage.  In addition, 2 visitor parking spots are provided on the west side of the driveway.

Rezoning application to permit a 50-storey tall residential tower including a 3-storey podium with grade related units for a total of 557 dwelling units.  The Gooderham mansion heritage building on the site would be relocated closer to Sherbourne Street with the residential tower to be located behind the building.  The application now inlcudes the property at 15 Selby Street with the existing building on the site being conserved,
To construct a secondary suite in the basement of the existing single family dwelling.

Proposed Zoning By-law Amendment application for a student residence building at the University of Toronto Scarborough.  The application is to allow for a 9-storey (32.85 m) building with a total Gross Floor Area (GFA) of 23,660 square metres.  The proposal includes 312 two-bedroom dormitory suites and one residential unit (approx 750 beds in total) along with 120 bicycle parking spaces (90 long term and 30 short term), 4 vehicle parking spaces and 2 loading spaces.

Proposed Student Residence at the University of Toronto Scarborough.  The proposed building includes 750 beds and ancillary student uses. The overall building height is 32.85 metres (9 storeys) plus mechanical penthouse. 4 short term accessible vehicular visitor parking spaces are proposed at grade.  90 indoor bicycle parking spaces and 30 outdoor bicycle parking spaces are proposed on the ground floor level.  Loading spaces and access to garbage staging areas are proposed along the east facade of the building.  Driveway access to the site is from Ellesmere Road at the east end of the site.

Application for Site Plan Approval to permit the development of two mixed-use buildings (Buildings A and B) comprised of four levels of underground parking, including 737 vehicle parking spaces, non-residential uses at the ground, 2nd, and part of the 3rd floors, and a total of 506 residential units. Building A is composed of 2 tower elements, the first having at a height of 19 storeys towards the north end of the site and sloping to 13 storeys closer to King Street West, the second at a height of 14 storeys. A 7-storey podium links to two tower elements of Building A fronting King Street West. Building B is a 12-story building with non residential space on the first three floors and residential units above. A new bike path situated adjacent to the rail corridor north of the building is proposed to connect Joe Shuster Way to Liberty Village.

Site Plan Control Application for proposed townhouses on the former Heron Park Public School site.  This application pertains to "Parcel B" of the lands, and proposes a total of 54 street related freehold townhouse units comprised of 46 units with integrated garages and rear yards, and 8 back-to-back freehold units with integrated garages all fronting onto a newly created public street.  The total GFA proposed for these units is 8,804 m2.  "Parcel B" comprises a total land area of 13,142.95 m2 of the entire 20,971.54 m2 site.

Related Site Plan Control Application for "Parcel A":  14 266726 ESC 44 SA.  Related OPA/Rezoning file 14 101641 ESC 44 OZ, and related Draft Plan of Subdivision application 14 101644 ESC 44 SB.  The OPA and Zoning Amendment are now in effect, and the Draft Plan of Subdivison has been registered as 66M-2537,

A Rezoning Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision application to re-develop the site with 8 new blocks, 6 new residential buildings,  a community centre, a public park, public roads and private driveways.  The buildings would range in height from 4 storeys to 25 storeys and contain a total of 941 new dwelling units consisting of townhouses and apartment units of which 341 are TCHC units and 600 are market units.  The units would consist of townhouses and apartment units.  The existing 152 TCHC apartment units at 5 Needle Firway would be retained. Building One would contain 123 TCHC units, Building Two would contain 218 TCHC units, Building Three would contain a community centre and daycare facilities, Building Four would contain 283 market units, Building Five would contain 48 market units, Building 7a would contain 142 market units and Building 7b would contain 127 market units.   A total of 667 parking spaces would be provided site wide. Properties include:  3, 36 Marsh Grassway, 7, 11 Blue Grassway, 4, 17 Cane Grassway, 5, 10, 40 Turf Grassway and 1,2, & 8 Dune Grassway.

A Rezoning Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision application to re-develop the site with 6 new residential buildings,  a community centre, a public park, public roads and private driveways.  The buildings would range in height from 4 storeys to 25 storeys and contain a total of 941 new dwelling units consisting of townhouses and apartment units of which 341 are TCHC units and 600 are market units.  The units would consist of townhouses and apartment units.  The existing 152 TCHC apartment units at 5 Needle Firway would be retained.  

Building One would contain 123 TCHC units, Building Two would contain 218 TCHC units, Building Three would contain a community centre and daycare facilities, Building Four would contain 283 market units, Building Five would contain 48 market units, Building 7a would contain 142 market units and Building 7b would contain 127 market units.   A total of 667 parking spaces would be provided site wide.

Properties include:  3, 36 Marsh Grassway, 7, 11 Blue Grassway, 4, 17 Cane Grassway, 5, 10, 40 Turf Grassway and 1,2, & 8 Dune Grassway.

Site plan approval submission to permit the construction of 314 residential units, and a minimum of 50,000 square feet of commercial space.  Located along the Warden Avenue frontage at Deans Drive will be a mid-rise mixed use building containing a maximum of 130 apartment units and a minimum of 17,200 square feet of commercial space on the ground floor.  Two commercial totalling over 32,700 square feet are located further north on the site. The remainder of the site will be occupied by a stormwater management pond and a City park.

Proposed 277-unit, 18-storey residential condominium building behind the three existing 15-storey rental apartment buildings containing 569 units. The proposal also includes 12 new rental units within the existing  buildings in spaces that currently contain a convenience store, ground level storage and maintenance rooms and a place of worship. The site would be severed into two parcels: one containing the existing buildings along Danforth Road; the other containing the new building. An easement would be created between the two landowners to facilitate permanent access to the new building.

This application proposes to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-laws (City-wide Zoning By-law No. 569-2013, former City of Toronto Zoning By-law No. 438-86 and former City of York Zoning By-law No. 1-83) to permit additional potentially sensitive non-residential uses on the lands at 150 Symes Road. A range of uses are proposed including office, light industrial, brewery, commercial school, clinic, indoor recreation uses such as a rock-climbing, fitness and dance, as well as multi-purpose rooms for art gallery and private event uses, including food service (indoors and outdoors). The proposed development would include the re-use of the existing heritage building and existing service garage, plus the addition of four new buildings on the west and north portions of the site

This application is for consent to create easements over the land at 1340, 1350 and 1360 Danforth Road in favour of the land at 1346 Danforth Road. The owners of 1346 Danforth Road are proposing to develop the land with an 18-storey, 277-unit residential apartment building. The land at 1346 Danforth Road was created by severance from the land at 1340, 1350 and 1360 Danforth Road. The owners have determined that it is necessary to obtain easements over portions of the remainder land for the purposes of providing residents with access to the proposed building from Danforth Road, and access to various outdoor amenity areas on the properties. Toronto City Council passed By-law No. 392-2015 on April 2, 2015 to permit the proposed development (File No. 12 247037 ESC 38 OZ). The applicants also submitted an application for Site Plan Approval for the development (File No. 14 104488 ESC 38 SA).

The townhouses will have a shared rearyard driveway accessed off of Hillcrest Ave.

Site Plan Control Application for proposed townhouses on the former Heron Park Public School site.  This application pertains to "Parcel B" of the lands, and proposes a total of 54 street related freehold townhouse units comprised of 46 units with integrated garages and rear yards, and 8 back-to-back freehold units with integrated garages all fronting onto a newly created public street.  The total GFA proposed for these units is 8,804 m2.  "Parcel B" comprises a total land area of 13,142.95 m2 of the entire 20,971.54 m2 site.

Related Site Plan Control Application for "Parcel A":  14 266726 ESC 44 SA.  Related OPA/Rezoning file 14 101641 ESC 44 OZ, and related Draft Plan of Subdivision application 14 101644 ESC 44 SB.  The OPA and Zoning Amendment are now in effect, and the Draft Plan of Subdivison has been registered as 66M-2537,

Site Plan Approval Application for the proposed 41-storey mixed-use building.

The purpose of the site plan re-submission is to revise the existing site plan application to reflect the decision of the Committee of Adjustment. 

Background:  In 2016, Site Plan Control approval was granted for a 37-storey mixed use building, including a 7-storey base building. On May 17, 2018, the Committee of Adjustment approved minor variance application A1330/17TEY to increase the overall gross floor area (residential and non-residential) of the building, increase the number of residential dwelling units, increase the maximum building height, reduce the number of parking spaces and decrease the amount of outdoor amenity space.

Rezoning application to permit the redevelopment of the lands for the purposes of a new mixed use building comprised of two residential towers 58 stories and  36 stories in height respectively connected by a 3 storey podium containing retail and office uses. Included in the proposal is the demolition and replacement of 30 existing rental dwelling units secured through a related Residential Demolition Control Application.  Proposal will contain 830 dwelling units complete with 350 parking spaces located in a below grade parking facility, 70 of which would be provided for retail and office purposes.

Application to permit 25, 3-storey townhouses on a new public road.  The subject  1.04 hectares is vacant and has a 36.78 m frontage on the west side of McCowan Road. The proposed development includes a number of mid-rise and tall buildings, ranging in height from 28-storeys on Bathurst Street, and stepping down toward the south and west. A total of 23 of the 27 listed heritage buildings on the site are being retained and incorporated into the development. The revised proposal comprises a total of 804 residential units in 59,883 square metres of residential floor area, and 15,253 square metres of new non-residential uses. The overall density of the proposal is FSI of 5.69 times the site, inclusive of retained heritage buildings, and 5.29 times the area of the site, exclusive of retained heritage buildings.  Access to underground parking is proposed from Lennox Street. A total of 480 underground vehicle parking spaces, 14 underground loading spaces, and 1038 bike parking spaces are proposed on site. The application also proposes 1150 square metres of on-site parkland and a new 440 square metre day nursery.  East Block File Number - 15 188751 STE 19 OZ (This is the Primary File Number). Revised application proposes 121 rental dwelling units on the northern portion of the site in five, 4-storey buildings comprising 87 back-to-back stacked  townhouse units and 34 apartment units and proposes 642 condominium dwelling units on the southern portion of the site in two buildings with heights ranging from 6 to 12 and 6 to 18 storeys. Application proposes a condominium apartment building on the southern portion of the site and rental townhouse and apartment buildng units on the northern half of the site. The condominium compomemt comprises a 3 to 17-storey apartment building wing along the south edge of the site connected to a 4 to 11-storey apartment building wing along the Leslie Street containing a total of 499 dwelling units and 629 parking spaces. The existing rental townhouse units on the site managed by Toronto Community Housing would be replaced and are proposed on the northern portion of the site and would comprise 115 rental replacement units in two 2, 3-storey townhouse blocks containing a total of 48 units and a 4-storey apartment building along Leslie Sttreet containing 67 dweliing units. The redevelopment of the site also includes a new public road and a privately owned publicly-accessible open space. This Official Plan Amendment application proposes that the City grant a permanent easement to Toronto Hydro Electric System Limited (Toronto Hydro) in order to permit Toronto Hydro to continue to use a portion of City owned parklands at 300 MacPherson Avenue and 235 Cottingham Street for below grade electrical services that were installed in 2014. A temporary short term easement  was previously granted for a two year period pending determinations as to final approval. An Official Plan Amendment is required to proceed because the property is designated as Parks and Open Space Areas under the Toronto Official Plan. The sale or disposal of City owned Parks and Open Space Areas is prohibited by Official Plan policies and the granting of an easement exceeding a period of 21 years is a form of disposal that is not permitted.

This application is for consent to sever the land at 5789, 5827, 5883, 5933, 5945, and 5951 Steeles Avenue East into two parcels, as shown on the attached Consent Sketch. The Committee of Adjustment previously gave provisional consent to this severance on two occasions, but each approval lapsed because the conditions were not fulfilled within one year. The conveyed lot would have a frontage of 302.2 m, with a depth of 272.4 m and an area of 83,780 m2. The retained lot would have a frontage of 627.6 m, with depth of 266.6 m and an area of 80,420 m2. The land shown as Part 2 would be dedicated to the City for an extension of State Crown Boulevard.  The land shown as Part 4, 5, and 6 would be dedicated to the City for the widening of Steeles Avenue East. In August, 2014, the Committee gave provisional consent to the creation of six parcels of land on the west side of the proposed State Crown Boulevard extension. Five of the proposed parcels would comprise part of Phase 1 of the Mosaic Shopping Centre development with frontages on Steeles Avenue East. The severance is not complete. (This property is also the subject of an application to amend for Site Plan Approval under file number 14 143954  ESC 42 SA).

Application proposes a condominium apartment building on the southern portion of the site and rental townhouse and apartment buildng units on the northern half of the site. The condominium compomemt comprises a 3 to 17-storey apartment building wing along the south edge of the site connected to a 4 to 11-storey apartment building wing along the Leslie Street containing a total of 499 dwelling units and 629 parking spaces. The existing rental townhouse units on the site managed by Toronto Community Housing would be replaced and are proposed on the northern portion of the site and would comprise 115 rental replacement units in two 2, 3-storey townhouse blocks containing a total of 48 units and a 4-storey apartment building along Leslie Sttreet containing 67 dweliing units. The redevelopment of the site also includes a new public road and a privately owned publicly-accessible open space.  The lands are also subject to applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law (File No. 11 330323 NNY 33 OZ), Rental Housing Demolition (11 331382 NNY 33 RH) and Draft Plan of Subdivision (14 134708 NNY 33 SB).

Proposed Official Plan Amendment and Rezoning to permit the development of 37 residential stacked and stacked back to back townhouses within 3 separate buildings. The buildings are arranged in an east-west configuration parallel to Gerrard St. E.   A total of 4,166 m2 of residential gross floor area is proposed on the 0.33 ha site.  The two buildings closest to Gerrard St. E. are proposed to have 4-storeys plus roof top amenity area, with the tallest building closest to Gerrard Street.  The third building at the back of the site is proposed to be 3-storeys tall and has no rooftop amenity area.  A total of 54 vehicular parking spaces (46 for residents including 16 tandem spaces, and 8 visitor) and a loading space are proposed in an underground parking garage, accessed from Gerrard St. E.  Related Site Plan Control Application 15 197250 ESC 36 SA.

The application proposes to redevelop the subject lands (Block B) with two rental apartment buildings of 38-storeys (Building B1) and 44-storeys (Building B2), connected by a 4-storey podium. The proposed development would have a total gross floor area of 68,330.73 square metres consisting of 67,943 square metres of residential uses and 822.47 square metres of retail/commercial space. The applicant's concept plan proposes two condominium apartment buildings of 13 and 12 storeys having a total of 276 dwelling units and a maximum height of approximately 44 metres (144 feet) located on the western portion of the site.  These buildings would be connected by a 2-storey lobby and common amenity building and include 1,065 m2 of commercial space on the ground floors of the two towers.  Proposed on the eastern portion of the site are 30 three storey townhouse units in 6 blocks.  A total of 314 residential parking spaces are proposed of which 35 would be dedicated for visitors.  Parking for the towers would be provided in a multi-level below grade parking garage having 284 spaces and 30 parking spaces would be provided within at-grade garages for the townhouses.  The development is proposed to be served by private streets with access provided from a driveway off Tippett Road.

This application has been submitted in support of an Official Plan Amendment application submitted in November 2011.  Proposed are two condominium apartment buildings of 13 and 12 storeys located on the western portion of the site having a total of 290 dwelling units including 22 live-work units.  The maximum building height is approximately 46 metres.  These buildings would be connected by a 2-storey lobby and common amenity building.  Proposed on the eastern portion of the site are 30 three storey townhouse units in 6 blocks.  A total of 360 residential parking spaces are proposed of which 59 would be dedicated for visitors.  Parking for the towers would be provided in a multi-level below grade parking garage having 330 spaces and 30 parking spaces would be provided within below grade garages for the townhouses.  Access to the site is proposed from a private drivway along the southern portion of the site that is eventually to become a new public road.  the associated Official Plan Amendment file is   (X-ref: 11 312374 NNY 10 OZ).

Update (august 2015)  Two buildings are proposed on site. The western building will be 12 storeys high with 242 units and 17,692m2 of gfa.  the east building proposes 8 storeys, 154 units and 10,661m2 of gfa.  the residential units will be a mix of townhouses and apartments.

Approximately 100 of the proposed dwellings will be affordable units with half being ownership and half being rental including 5 townhouse units. 

The resulting By-law is 1361-2015.


213 parking spaces are proposed in a 1-level underground parking garage.

Proposed Official Plan Amendment and Rezoning Application to permit the development of 121 stacked townhouse units within seven (7) buildings.

Site Plan Control Application to permit the development of 121 stacked townhouse units within seven (7) buildings.  Two of the seven buildings are parallel to Clonmore Dr, the remainder are internal to the site.  Building heights are 13.5m. The total gross floor area proposed is 11,943.4 sq. m.  A total of 168 parking spaces are proposed, including 143 spaces for residents, including 6 barrier free spaces, and 23 spaces for visitors, including 1 barrier free space.  Most parking spaces are located within an underground parking garage, with the exception of 2 of the visitor spaces which are proposed at grade.  A total of 114 bicycle parking spaces are proposed (80 for residents within the underground garage, and 24 surface visitor spaces).  Access to the interior of the site and the underground parking is provided via a private driveway from Clonmore Drive located opposite Queensbury Avenue. The site is 1 hectare (2.46 acres) in size and backs onto the Metrolinx/GO rail corridor.    Related OPA and Rezoning file 15 106475 ESC 36 OZ.

The owners are proposing to convey land to create 17 freehold lots for townhouse development and a private common element condominium roadway. The proposed lots are shown as Parts 1 to 17 on the attached Lot Division Plan, and the proposed private roadway is shown as Part 18. This proposal was previously reviewed by area residents through applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law. City Council passed a zoning amendment in June, 2006 to permit the project. Although the project has not changed, the owners are asking for variances to the By-law that would allow the property to be divided into individual lots for the 17 proposed townhouses.

The owners are seeking consent in order to divide the irregular shaped subject lands into 2 residential lots shown as Part 1 and Part 2 on the attached Lot Division Plan. Part 1 has a frontage of 10.65 metres (35 feet) and an area of approximately 985 square metres (10,602 square feet). Part 2 has a frontage of 12.47 metres (41 feet) and an area of  approximately 985 square metres (10,602 square feet). Proposal Description:

Submission of a site plan application for the Retail and Office components of the development of the former Globe and Mail site (Master Sipe Plan submission). This application includes the underground parking, retail and office components of the site plan application to permit a comprehensive development of the former Globe and Mail site (aka. The Well).  The project, now under construction, includes seven mixed-use buildings comprising retail, office and residential uses.  A maximum of 289,000 square metres of gross floor area includes 102,797 square metres office space; 47,290 square metres of retail space and 132,923 square metres of residential space.  A total of 1,681 residential units are proposed.  See Zoning By-laws 124-2017 and 125-2017.  Four site plan applications have been submitted and are under review comprising the residential component of the development.

The owners are proposing to convey land to create 17 freehold lots for townhouse development and a private common element condominium roadway. The proposed lots are shown as Parts 1 to 17 on the attached Lot Division Plan, and the proposed private roadway is shown as Part 18. This proposal was previously reviewed by area residents through applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law. City Council passed a zoning amendment in June, 2006 to permit the project. Although the project has not changed, the owners are asking for variances to the By-law that would allow the property to be divided into individual lots for the 17 proposed townhouses.

This application has been submitted as an amendment to an existing site plan approval issued on May 28, 2009 for an addition to an existing single-family dwelling.  The owner has had to submit an amending application due to the extent of the changes being proposed to the approved elevations particularly the west elevation.  Please cross-reference site plan application 09 106675 ESC 36 SA.

Site Plan Control Application to permit the development of 121 stacked townhouse units within seven (7) buildings.  Two of the seven buildings are parallel to Clonmore Dr, the remainder are internal to the site.  Building heights are 13.5m. The total gross floor area proposed is 11,943.4 sq. m.  A total of 168 parking spaces are proposed, including 143 spaces for residents, including 6 barrier free spaces, and 23 spaces for visitors, including 1 barrier free space.  Most parking spaces are located within an underground parking garage, with the exception of 2 of the visitor spaces which are proposed at grade.  A total of 114 bicycle parking spaces are proposed (80 for residents within the underground garage, and 24 surface visitor spaces).  Access to the interior of the site and the underground parking is provided via a private driveway from Clonmore Drive located opposite Queensbury Avenue. The site is 1 hectare (2.46 acres) in size and backs onto the Metrolinx/GO rail corridor.    Related OPA and Rezoning file 15 106475 ESC 36 OZ.

Proposed Official Plan Amendment and Rezoning Application to permit the development of 121 stacked townhouse units within seven (7) buildings.

Site Plan Control Application to permit the development of 121 stacked townhouse units within seven (7) buildings.  Two of the seven buildings are parallel to Clonmore Dr, the remainder are internal to the site.  Building heights are 13.5m. The total gross floor area proposed is 11,943.4 sq. m.  A total of 168 parking spaces are proposed, including 143 spaces for residents, including 6 barrier free spaces, and 23 spaces for visitors, including 1 barrier free space.  Most parking spaces are located within an underground parking garage, with the exception of 2 of the visitor spaces which are proposed at grade.  A total of 114 bicycle parking spaces are proposed (80 for residents within the underground garage, and 24 surface visitor spaces).  Access to the interior of the site and the underground parking is provided via a private driveway from Clonmore Drive located opposite Queensbury Avenue. The site is 1 hectare (2.46 acres) in size and backs onto the Metrolinx/GO rail corridor.    Related OPA and Rezoning file 15 106475 ESC 36 OZ.

The rezoning application is to rezone the site from Industrial Commercial Zone (MC) in the Scarborough Employment District Zoning By-law No. 24982 to Townhouse Residential (TH) in the Midland/St. Clair Zoning By-law No. 842-2002 to permit a 48 townhouse unit development in five building blocks and to introduce site specific provisions including setbacks, height (at 3 storeys) and visitor parking standards.  The plan of subdivision is to create a public street and blocks for the townhouse development.

The Unilever Precinct Secondary Plan (OPA 411) and the East Harbour Zoning By-laws (2018-1280 and 2018-1281) were approved by Council and came into force in the summer of 2018. Enbridge Gas Distribution Inc. ("EGO") leases a 40.94m2 portion of land from the City of Toronto, which is located within Woodbine Park in the City of Toronto. EGO has been leasing the lands for over 20 years. The lands are designated in the Official Plan as Park, and the City of Toronto - Real Estate Services division has indicated that a lease renewal on the subject lands would be considered a disposal of Parks and Open Space lands as per Section 4.3.8 of the Official Plan. In order to rectify this matter, the City of Toronto Real Estate Services division has requested that EGO apply for a Site Specific Official Plan Amendment. An exemption of the leased lands from Section 4.3.8 of the Official Plan would allow the City of Toronto to renew EGO's lease of the subject lands.
