A Rezoning Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision application to re-develop the site with 8 new blocks, 6 new residential buildings,  a community centre, a public park, public roads and private driveways.  The buildings would range in height from 4 storeys to 25 storeys and contain a total of 941 new dwelling units consisting of townhouses and apartment units of which 341 are TCHC units and 600 are market units.  The units would consist of townhouses and apartment units.  The existing 152 TCHC apartment units at 5 Needle Firway would be retained. Building One would contain 123 TCHC units, Building Two would contain 218 TCHC units, Building Three would contain a community centre and daycare facilities, Building Four would contain 283 market units, Building Five would contain 48 market units, Building 7a would contain 142 market units and Building 7b would contain 127 market units.   A total of 667 parking spaces would be provided site wide. Properties include:  3, 36 Marsh Grassway, 7, 11 Blue Grassway, 4, 17 Cane Grassway, 5, 10, 40 Turf Grassway and 1,2, & 8 Dune Grassway.

This application is for variances for proposed interior alterations and a second floor addition to convert existing offices and vacant industrial space to an adult post-secondary school. The property is split between two zones in the zoning by-law. The north part of the property is zoned Industrial (M), which allows an educational facility. The south part of the property is zoned Industrial District Commercial (MDC), which does not allow the use. The applicants are requesting a variance to allow the entire building to be used for the school, along with the other variances described below.

Site Plan application to permit the construction of four buildings on the block bounded by Lower Sherbourne Street, Princess Avenue, The Esplanade and Front Street  East. It is proposed to construct two 29-storey buildings connected by a 16-storey building that steps down to a 10-storey building to the south. The two 29-storey buildings step down three times along Lower Sherbourne Street and Princess Street reaching a height of 11-storeys along The Esplanade. Along The Esplanade, a Privately Owned Publically Accessible space measuring 1,608 sq.m. is provided. In total, the buildings would include 1,927 sq.m. of non-residential uses and 1,531 residential units. A Rezoning Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision application to re-develop the site with 6 new residential buildings,  a community centre, a public park, public roads and private driveways. The units would consist of townhouses and apartment units.  The existing 152 TCHC apartment units at 5 Needle Firway would be retained.  

Building One would contain 123 TCHC units, Building Two would contain 218 TCHC units, Building Three would contain a community centre and daycare facilities, Building Four would contain 283 market units, Building Five would contain 48 market units, Building 7a would contain 142 market units and Building 7b would contain 127 market units. East Donlands Official Plan Amendment -  The purpose of the OPA application is to initiate a policy review to begin comprehensive planning of the Unilever site and adjacent lands.The Planning Rationale includes a draft Official Plan Amendment which proposes a policy framework for the development of a broad variety of non-residential land uses providing employment opportunities for approximately 50,000 workers. The proposed OPA is a policy initiative, not a development proposal.  The only drawings submitted are a survey.  The applicant has provided no plans, conceptual or otherwise, for actual development.

Council approved the Unilever Precinct Secondary Plan (OPA 411) and East Harbour zoning by-laws in July 2018.  Secondary Plan sets policy for the entire 25 hectare precinct.  East Harbour by-laws (Zoning By-laws No. 1280-2018 and 1281-2018) detail implementation on the 21 Don Valley Parkway, 30 Booth Avenue, and 375 and 385 Eastern Avenue lands.  There were no appeals.

The East Harbour Plan of Subdivision was resubmitted March 7, 2019.  The original submission occurred along with the December 2016 rezoning application (file no. 16 270071 30 OZ).  The Unilever Precinct Secondary Plan (OPA 411) and the East Harbour Zoning By-laws (2018-1280 and 2018-1281) were approved by Council and came into force in the summer of 2018.  The Plan of Subdivision has now been updated to reflect the East Harbour approvals, as well as to advance First Gulf's current proposed phasing and infrastructure delivery strategy.

Site Plan Approval Application for the redevelopment and adaptive re-use of the Soap Factory Building at East Harbour. The Soap Factory Building is the first phase of a comprehensive, master planned commercial redevelopment in the Unilever Precinct, enabled by the Unilever Precinct Secondary Plan (OPA 411) and the East Harbour Zoning By-laws (By-laws No. 1280-2018 and 1281-2018), encompassing a broad variety of non-residential uses.

Each phase, as developed, was treated as a separate parcel requiring the by-law's regulations to be calculated and applied separately.  The applicant now proposes to complete the development of the remainder of the lands, identified as Parts 5 and 6 on Reference Plan 66R-19597 (filed with the application), with a three-storey office building fronting on Silver Star Boulevard and two, single-storey commercial buildings fronting on Midland Avenue.  The applicant is also proposing outdoor patios in conjunction with two restaurants within commercial buildings already constructed that front on McNicoll Avenue and is requesting that the remainder of the development phases be dealt with collectively.  The site, although divided, will operate as one parcel through mutual easements.

The owners of the property at 300 Danforth Rd are proposing a development consisting of approximately 258 to 281 dwelling units in various housing forms, including stacked townhouses, rear lane townhouses, street townhouses and semi-detached houses. The development includes a 128-unit seniors' apartment building with commerical uses on a block with frontage on Danforth Road. A draft plan of subdivision incorporating all of this land was approved in principle by Council in 2006 (File 05 188717 ESC 35 SB). The owners are now requesting consent to sever the land to create two parcels to allow the land to be developed in two phases, under separate ownership. The land to be retained by the owner is a 0.713 ha parcel with frontage on Danforth Road, and is shown as Part 1 on the Lot Division Plan. This land is also identified as Blocks 1 and 2 on the Draft Plan of Subdivision, and includes the block of land zoned for senior citizens' apartments. The land to be conveyed is a 2.952 ha parcel shown as Part 2 on the Lot Division Plan, and includes the remaining land to be developed for residential uses, shown on the Draft Plan of Subdivision.

Site Plan Control Application to permit the development of 121 stacked townhouse units within seven (7) buildings.  Two of the seven buildings are parallel to Clonmore Dr, the remainder are internal to the site.  Building heights are 13.5m. The total gross floor area proposed is 11,943.4 sq. m.  A total of 168 parking spaces are proposed, including 143 spaces for residents, including 6 barrier free spaces, and 23 spaces for visitors, including 1 barrier free space.  Most parking spaces are located within an underground parking garage, with the exception of 2 of the visitor spaces which are proposed at grade.  A total of 114 bicycle parking spaces are proposed (80 for residents within the underground garage, and 24 surface visitor spaces).  Access to the interior of the site and the underground parking is provided via a private driveway from Clonmore Drive located opposite Queensbury Avenue. The site is 1 hectare (2.46 acres) in size and backs onto the Metrolinx/GO rail corridor.    Related OPA and Rezoning file 15 106475 ESC 36 OZ.

To permit a six-storey mixed use building containing a healing lodge and transitional housing with retail space on the ground floor. A healing lodge is a Residential Care Facility that provides a culturally-relevant, restorative care setting to aid Indigenous women who are making a transition from the correctional system into the community. The proposed healing lodge would include twelve residences and gathering spaces for cultural programming. More information about this proposal, including details about the cultural programming proposed by the Thunder Woman Healing Lodge Society, are available online at the Application Information Centre at www.toronto.ca/aic.

To construct a six storey condominium with 17 residential suites, a commercial unit on the ground floor, and an underground parking garage. A previous minor variance application was approved by the Committee of Adjustment on September 5, 2013 for variances related to first floor height, building setbacks, balcony setbacks and parking (File # A169/13SC). The owners are now proposing the addition of three balconies along Queensbury Avenue and a rooftop terrace. This terrace requires a roof access system with a vestibule and as such, the height of the building and building setbacks (stepbacks) is to be measured to the rooftop vestibule.  The vestibule does not encompass the entire roof area but only affects a small area as shown on the attached Roof Plan.  The total gross floor area of the building excluding the rooftop terrace area is substantially in accordance with the 2013 site plans and elevations. The proposed balconies along Queensbury Avenue will not be located on the upper storeys of the building. Two of the balconies are to be located on the third floor and the remaining balcony on the fourth floor. A Site Plan application is currently under review (File # 13 149434 ESC 36 SA).

9-storey, plus roof-top mechanical mid-rise building containing 80 (+ 1 guest suite) residential units with a total gross floor area of approximately 8 092 square metres and an associated two level, below-grade parking structure containing a total of 87 vehicle parking spaces, 63 bicycle parking spaces, mechanical rooms, elevator shaft, lockers and other uses
This application is for variances for a proposed nine storey, 73-unit residential building.

This application is for variances for a proposed nine storey, 73-unit residential building. The Committee of Adjustment granted variances for this development in September, 2015 (File A279/14SC). Due to an zoning interpretation that requires certain utility and amenity features of the building to be included in the calculation of the gross floor area, the owners are requesting a variance to permit a gross floor area equal to 3.8 times the area of the lot, whereas the zoning by-law permits a maximum of 3.5 times the area of the lot. The proposed gross floor area includes utility and amenity features such as storage rooms, electrical, mechanical and utility rooms, elevator shafts, and exit stairwells. The built form and massing of the approved development have not changed. This development is also the subject of an application for site plan approval (File No. 20 13 280225 ESC 36 SA).

Standard condominium application for a 9-storey, plus roof-top mechanical mid-rise building containing 80 (+ 1 guest suite) residential units with a total gross floor area of approximately 8 092 square metres and an associated two level, below-grade parking structure containing a total of 87 vehicle parking spaces, 63 bicycle parking spaces, mechanical rooms, elevator shaft, lockers and other uses.

This application is for an additional variance for the nine storey, 73-unit residential building currently under construction. The Committee of Adjustment granted variances for this development in September, 2015 (File A279/14SC) and in June, 2016 (A153/16SC). The owners seeking relief from the Zoning By-law as a result of an alteration to a ninth-floor suite (Unit 801). The unit has been altered to include an additional second floor bedroom located above the ninth floor and this second bedroom space is utilizing a portion of the area that was originally dedicated to a mechanical room. The built form and massing of the approved development have not changed. This development is also the subject of an application for site plan approval (File No. 20 13 280225 ESC 36 SA).

The owners are requesting the consent of the Committee of Adjustment to convey land to create 17 freehold lots for townhouse development and a private common element condominium roadway. The proposed lots are shown as Parts 1 to 17 on the attached Lot Division Plan, and the proposed private roadway is shown as Part 18. This proposal was previously reviewed by area residents through applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law. City Council passed a zoning amendment in June, 2006 to permit the project. Although the project has not changed, the owners are asking for variances to the By-law that would allow the property to be divided into individual lots for the 17 proposed townhouses.

Proposed 7-storey mid-rise residential building containing a total GFA of 4,377 m² with a density of 3.06 FSI. A total of 41 units including 6 ground level units, four of which front Kingston Rd. A total of 45 vehicular parking spaces and 31 bicycle spaces are proposed. 28 of the 31 bicycle parking spaces and all vehicular parking spaces are to be located in a two storey underground parking structure. The site area is 1,430 m² and is currently occupied by three two-storey commercial buildings including a former vehicle service station at the corner of Cornell Ave and Kingston Rd. The subject site has a frontage of 42 m along Kingston and 28 m along Cornell Ave. The existing structures are to be demolished and replaced by the proposed 7-storey building.
The owners are proposing to develop the site with a seven storey, mid-rise condominium building with 41 residential units.

The owners are requesting the consent of the Committee of Adjustment to convey land to create 17 freehold lots for townhouse development and a private common element condominium roadway. The proposed lots are shown as Parts 1 to 17 on the attached Lot Division Plan, and the proposed private roadway is shown as Part 18. This proposal was previously reviewed by area residents through applications to amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-law. City Council passed a zoning amendment in June, 2006 to permit the project. Although the project has not changed, the owners are asking for variances to the By-law that would allow the property to be divided into individual lots for the 17 proposed townhouses.

The property at the southwest corner of Lawrence Avenue East and Birchmount Road is developed with a 12-storey, 243-unit residential building with at-grade commercial uses. This development was originally intended to be integrated with a development on the property to the south at 1236 Birchmount Road, including shared parking facilities. A by-law passed by City Council in 2006 (By-law No. 817-2006) required parking for residents, visitors and commercial uses to be provided collectively on both properties. At the time, the two properties were under affiliated ownership. The properties are now owned by separate entities. The owners of 2155 Lawrence Avenue are requesting a variance to require parking facilities to be provided on their property only, instead of collectively on both properties. The parking spaces currently provided on the property comply with the zoning requirements, and the number of parking spaces will not change.

The operators of Dolphin Bingo are proposing to undertake interior alterations to the building to convert the existing restaurant/bingo hall to an electronic gaming and bingo hall. They are proposing to operate electronic bingo in conjunction with the Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation's Charitable Bingo and Gaming Revitalization Initiative. Electronic bingo is bingo played on electronic terminals with touch screens. The proposed use is not permitted by the zoning by-law on this site. The Committee of Adjustment approved a variance in 1994 to permit a bingo hall on the property, subject to restrictions on the hours of operation. The Committee approved another variance in 1997 to permit the bingo hall with fewer restrictions on the hours of operation. In 2006, the Committee approved a further variance to permit the bingo hall without restrictions on the hours of operation. The applicants are now seeking relief from the by-law to permit the proposed electronic gaming and bingo hall.

To permit Dolphin Bingo to expand its electronic gaming bingo hall to include an adjacent 326 m2 unit. With the proposed expansion, the electronic gaming bingo hall would occupy a total gross floor area of 2,326 m2. The number of parking spaces on the site would remain at 478.

Zoning By-law amendment to apply zoning for five development blocks in a mixed use community.  Includes land known as 1-70 Eglinton Square, 1431 & 1437 Victoria Park Avenue, 14,18,19-23 & 26 Engelhart Crescent and 64, 68 Harris Park Drive. Stacked townhomes, two 8 storey mid-rise buildings and five mixed use towers ranging from 25 to 40 storeys on base buildings of 4-8 storeys.  Overall 1814 units of residential development representing 158,038 m2 of GFA and 24,662 m2 of non-residential GFA are proposed, for a total of 182,700 m2 (1,966,631 sq. ft.) of new GFA.  The existing Eglinton Square mall is proposed to be retained.

Second Submission:

The revised submission propose to establish a plan of subdivision and to amend the Zoning By-law for the entire 3.56 hectare site known municipally as 670, 680 and 690 Progress Avenue to permit the redevelopment of the lands in four blocks.

Block 1: 2 buildings at 16 and 38 storeys
Block 2: 1 building st 28 storeys
Block 3: 2 buildings at 8 and 44 storeys
Block 4A: 1 building at 37 storeys
Block 4B: 2 buildings at 16 and 60 storeys

A total of 3,029 residential dwelling units are proposed (previously 2,245 residential units); a total of 1,995 vehicular parking spaces are proposed (previously 1,654 vehicular parking spaces) are proposed in three levels below grade, one level at grade and two levels above grade.

This application is for a proposal to establish a Day Nursery for the care of more than five children in the building at 24 Progress Avenue. The east half of the building is currently used for the warehousing and wholesaling of theatrical supplies. The west half of the building is used for an arts/performing arts school and a child care facility for the care of not more than five children. The child care facility was established as an ancillary use in conjunction with the warehouse use, and was intended to give temporary care for the children of employees. Now the child care operator is proposing to increase enrolment in the program to accommodate more than five children. A facility that accommodates more than five children would be a Day Nursery, as defined by Toronto Zoning By-law No. 569-2013, and is not a permitted use in this location. A Day Nursery also requires a license under the Day Nurseries Act. The applicants made this application under s.45 (2)(a)(ii) of the Planning Act. Under this section of the Act, where a use existed lawfully before the zoning by-law was passed, the Committee of Adjustment may permit a use that is similar to the purpose for which it was used on the day the by-law was passed or is more compatible with the uses permitted by the by-law than the purpose for which it was used on the day the by-law was passed. The applicants are requesting such permission.

Global Kingdom Ministries is proposing to build two additions and undertake interior renovations to the existing place of worship building. The proposed additions would be located on the north and south sides of the building and would increase the total floor area by 2,307 m2. The additions would be used for an expanded nursery, meeting rooms, an audio and video production studio, and a lounge area. There are 464 existing parking spaces on the place of worship site. The applicants are proposing to re-stripe the parking area to provide an additional 22 parking spaces (486 spaces in total). The zoning by-law requires 633 parking spaces, and the applicants are requesting a variance to permit a parking shortfall of 147 spaces.

Application to rezone the subject properties for a residential development comprised of 26 residential lots with single detached dwellings accessed by a one-way private road to and from Warden Avenue. City Council adopted item SC31.4 and By-law Nos 811-2018 and 812-2018 were enacted on June 29, 2018.

The owners are proposing to build a new single family dwelling and are requesting relief from the Zoning By-law's minimum lot frontage and side yard building setback requirement. The existing dwelling and garage would be demolished.
To construct an attached garage on the south side of the existing single family dwelling.
To construct a two-storey side and rear (L-shaped) addition to the existing dwelling, which would impact upon the size and siting of the parking space on the south side of the house.
The applicant is seeking relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to permit the built carport attached to the one storey dwelling.
This application is to obtain consent to sever the property into two undersized residential lots.

To construct a new detached dwelling with integral garage and rear deck.

(OMB HEARING SET FOR JANUARY 6, 2017 @ 10:00 A.M.)

These applications are for variances to reduce the required rear yard setback for the industrial buildings at 2000 and 2020 Ellesmere Road. The owners are proposing to sever the land shown as Parts 1 and 2 on the attached Lot Division Plan and convey the land as lot additions to the adjacent property at 2010 Ellesmere Road. Parts 1 and 2 comprise the rear 2.5 m of the lots at 2020 and 2000 Ellesmere Road respectively. By conveying the land, the setback between the rear walls of the buildings and the proposed rear lot lines would be reduced. The owners are seeking relief from the rear yard setback requirement. Notice of the applications to sever the lands will be given separately (Files B012/14SC and B013/14SC).
This application is for a variance to permit an after school tutoring facility in the existing building at 2020 Ellesmere Road (Unit 2).
To construct a new two-storey north side addition with an integral garage, and a new second storey addition. The alterations include a second suite with separate access.
The applicant is seeking relief from the provisions of the Zoning By-law to permit the growing of micro greens in the existing organic food processing company, Crown Sprouts.
To construct a 185.8 m² rear addition to the existing Place of Worship building.
To construct a rear addition onto the existing Animal Care Centre.

Parking lot expansion at existing Bell Facility including reconfiguration of existing 230 parking spaces to 167 spaces, paving of the rear gravelled portion of the lot to provide a further 208 spaces, and installation of 7 new catch basins for storm water management purposes.  File to be closed (application not required).
Site plan control for interior alterations to convert existing industrial building to a  Place of Worship with associated Day Nursery.
